summary: A company retained personal data even after the user requested anonymization.
An online service refused to delete data, citing inability to identify the user.
A data controller failed to implement measures to ensure anonymous processing.
A website linked user behavior to profiles despite an opt-out request.
An organization processed data beyond necessity without means of identifying users.
A company did not notify third parties of a user’s request to delete personal data.
A bank failed to inform credit bureaus about a user’s corrected financial records.
An online retailer ignored the obligation to update third parties about data changes.
A healthcare provider did not inform insurance companies of updated patient data.
A social media platform refused to notify advertisers about deleted user accounts.
A music streaming service denied users the ability to export their playlists.
A telecom provider refused to provide customer call records in a structured format.
An insurance company failed to transfer policyholder data to a competitor.
A cloud storage provider made data migration to another service impossible.
A banking app did not allow customers to download their transaction history.
A government agency imposed data access restrictions without clear legal justification.
A telecom company limited user data deletion requests citing security concerns.
A financial institution restricted account holders from exporting their own data.
A medical research project refused data deletion requests without valid reasons.
A national security law was used to block access to personal data without oversight.
A certification body issued GDPR compliance certificates without proper audits.
A company falsely claimed GDPR certification without independent verification.
An organization failed to meet renewal requirements for GDPR certification.
A GDPR compliance certification was revoked due to lack of oversight.
A certification body had conflicts of interest when approving GDPR compliance.
A social media company transferred EU user data to the US without safeguards.
An e-commerce site stored customer data on foreign servers without legal grounds.
A multinational firm processed EU customer data outside the EU without compliance.
A cloud provider moved client data to non-EU jurisdictions without proper protections.
A financial institution shared EU citizen data with a foreign partner unlawfully.
A company transferred personal data abroad without using Standard Contractual Clauses.
A healthcare provider shared patient data internationally without encryption.
An online service failed to implement safeguards for cross-border data transfers.
A retail company moved customer data to another country without binding agreements.
A software company processed EU user data in non-compliant regions without safeguards.
A website collected personal data from children under 13 without parental consent.
An app failed to verify parental consent before processing data of minors.
A social media platform allowed underage users to register without age verification.
A gaming company processed data of minors without informing parents.
A school platform shared students' personal data without proper consent.
A company unlawfully processed criminal records of employees without justification.
A background check service stored criminal data for longer than legally allowed.
A financial institution used criminal data for profiling without consent.
A law firm shared a client's criminal record with third parties without consent.
A public database exposed individuals' past criminal convictions without legal basis.
A bank refused to correct incorrect credit scores despite user requests.
An e-commerce site failed to update incorrect customer addresses upon request.
A health provider denied a patient’s request to fix incorrect medical records.
A telecom company ignored requests to update incorrect billing details.
A university kept outdated student records despite multiple requests for correction.
A bank denied loans based solely on automated credit scoring without human review.
An employer used an AI-based hiring system that rejected candidates unfairly.
An insurance company increased premiums based on an opaque AI algorithm.
A job-matching platform used AI decisions without transparency or user consent.
A telecom provider blocked services using an automated risk assessment system.
A company transferred customer data to a country without an adequacy decision.
A tech firm processed EU citizens’ data in a country lacking data protection laws.
An online retailer stored EU customer data in servers located in a non-compliant country.
A healthcare provider shared patient data with a non-EU company without safeguards.
A cloud service provider moved sensitive data to a jurisdiction without proper oversight.
A user requested processing restriction, but the company continued using their data.
A bank denied a customer's request to temporarily restrict the processing of their data.
An online retailer ignored a user's request to limit data processing during a dispute.
A social media platform failed to pause data processing despite a pending verification issue.
A telecom provider refused to limit data usage for a user contesting billing errors.
